citations.narrative:
An enclosure housing three Gambles Quail had a large hole in the enclosure wire. The hole in the enclosure was
approximately 3 feet long and created a large gap in the enclosure that is approximately 6 inches wide.
A facility representative repaired this hole by placing fastening devices on the wire enclosure at the time of inspection.
Failure to ensure that enclosures are appropriately constructed can result in predators gaining access to the animals,
injury/death, and possible escape.
The facility must ensure that housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally
sound for the species of bird housed in them and protect the birds from injury. Correct by 20-November-2024.

The facility is providing an insufficient amount of shelter for the hoof stock in the outdoor drive-through section of the
facility. The drive-through section of the facility contains numerous species including but not limited to bison, elk, cattle,
and zebra which totals about at least 300 animals. The drive-through section contains 4 shelters with openings measuring
approximately 32 inches in height and 4 hay shelters with openings measuring approximately 27 inches wide and
approximately 48 inches in height. These structures are inadequate as they are not large enough for all the individuals of
these species to utilize them for shelter.
The facility does have ravines and other forms of windbreaks, but they provide either minimal or no overhead protection
from the elements. Due to the change in season following the last inspection, the trees have also lost most or all their
foliage. The facility does have a section of the barn that they state is approximately 60 feet by 60 feet, but it was closed off
to the hoof stock at the time of inspection. The barn does have a roof overhang, but it does not provide side protection
from the elements.
Failure to provide shelter from inclement weather can result in discomfort to the animals during wind, rain, snow, or other
hazardous conditions. Natural or artificial shelter appropriate to the local climatic conditions for the species concerned
shall be provided for all animals kept outdoors to afford them protection and to prevent discomfort to such animals.
Correct by providing adequate shelter to all animals at all times. Correct by 20-December-2024.
This inspection was conducted with Facility Representatives. An exit interview was unable to be performed.
Additional Inspectors:
Jonathan Tomkovitch, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.150(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
An enclosure housing three Gambles Quail had a large hole in the enclosure wire. The hole in the enclosure was 
approximately 3 feet long and created a large gap in the enclosure that is approximately 6 inches wide.  
 
A facility representative repaired this hole by placing fastening devices on the wire enclosure at the time of inspection.  
 
Failure to ensure that enclosures are appropriately constructed can result in predators gaining access to the animals, 
injury/death, and possible escape.  
 
The facility must ensure that housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally 
sound for the species of bird housed in them and protect the birds from injury. Correct by 20-November-2024. 
3.127(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The facility is providing an insufficient amount of shelter for the hoof stock in the outdoor drive-through section of the 
facility. The drive-through section of the facility contains numerous species including but not limited to bison, elk, cattle, 
and zebra which totals about at least 300 animals. The drive-through section contains 4 shelters with openings measuring 
approximately 32 inches in height and 4 hay shelters with openings measuring approximately 27 inches wide and 
approximately 48 inches in height. These structures are inadequate as they are not large enough for all the individuals of 
these species to utilize them for shelter. 
 
The facility does have ravines and other forms of windbreaks, but they provide either minimal or no overhead protection 
from the elements. Due to the change in season following the last inspection, the trees have also lost most or all their 
foliage. The facility does have a section of the barn that they state is approximately 60 feet by 60 feet, but it was closed off 
to the hoof stock at the time of inspection. The barn does have a roof overhang, but it does not provide side protection 
from the elements. 
 
Failure to provide shelter from inclement weather can result in discomfort to the animals during wind, rain, snow, or other 
hazardous conditions. Natural or artificial shelter appropriate to the local climatic conditions for the species concerned

shall be provided for all animals kept outdoors to afford them protection and to prevent discomfort to such animals. 
Correct by providing adequate shelter to all animals at all times. Correct by 20-December-2024. 
 
This inspection was conducted with Facility Representatives. An exit interview was unable to be performed. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Jonathan Tomkovitch, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
